# 6.3.2 Tighter bounds on probability masses 

In previous instances, the natural lower and upper bounds $L$ and $U$ on probability masses may have been relatively loose, necessitating tighter constraints using additional information. Our methodology integrates seamlessly with other knowledge available to the agent. For

instance, actively traded exotic options, such as digital options, can provide upper or lower bounds on probability densities due to their specific payoffs. Although we do not have access to such proprietary data, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method using artificial bounds. Readers can easily apply the same procedure once relevant data become available. In this subsection, we focus on the basket option (6.7) on GILD and GSK. Suppose the agent imposes the following constraints on the coupling $\pi$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \leq 0.01 \\
& \pi\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \geq \zeta \min \left\{\mu_{1}\left(x_{1}\right), \ldots, \mu_{N}\left(x_{N}\right), \nu_{1}\left(y_{1}\right), \ldots, \nu_{N}\left(y_{N}\right)\right\}, \text { for }\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \in \mathcal{A}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\zeta>0$ serves as a shrinking parameter, and $\mathcal{A}$ is a subset of paths where (6.10) holds. Empirically, there are typically more than 2,000 paths available for $\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)$. The upper bound of 0.01 in (6.9) ensures that the coupling $\pi$ does not concentrate excessively on too few paths; this value is chosen arbitrarily for demonstration purposes. For the lower bound (6.10), the agent specifies that certain paths of interest should have a sufficiently large probability. To make (6.9) and (6.10) feasible, we can set $\zeta \leq 0.01$. Lacking prior knowledge of the underlying assets GILD and GSK, the set $\mathcal{A}$ is chosen arbitrarily for demonstration. For each support $\mathcal{X}_{1}, \mathcal{X}_{2}, \mathcal{Y}_{1}$, and $\mathcal{Y}_{2}$, we select one-third of the possible stock prices in an equally spaced manner, resulting in the set $\mathcal{A}$ containing at most $1 / 81 \approx 1.23 \%$ of the paths. The set of McCormick martingale couplings $\mathcal{M}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu} ; L, U)$ can be empty after imposing (6.9) and (6.10). However, the existence of a McCormick martingale coupling can be numerically checked using LP solvers such as Gurobi.

Table 3 presents the statistics of the ratios obtained under different shrinking parameters $\zeta$ and maturities $T_{2}$. We consider $\zeta \in\{0.005,0.01\}$ for simplicity. The second maturity date $T_{2}$ can be $1,2,3$ or 4 weeks after the first maturity date $T_{1}$, where $T_{1}$ is the maturity date closest to the current time $T_{0}=0$. Overall, McCormick MOT yields much better price intervals when tighter bounds $L$ and $U$ are available. On average, the eight cases in Table 3 achieve a reduction of $12.26 \%$. The best instance, with a minimum ratio of 0.1405 , indicates a reduction of more than $80.00 \%$. Notably, the reductions here are relative to the classic MOT method with the same tighter constraints $L$ and $U$. Table 3 demonstrate that McCormick relaxations can further enhance price intervals, primarily because the inequalities like (5.3) become more effective. Besides, the performance of McCormick relaxations is better when the maturity $T_{2}$ is shorter since the number of paths is smaller, and the upper bound (6.9) is more likely to be binding. Generally, a larger parameter $\zeta$ results in greater improvements in price bounds. However, this is not always the case, as the set $\mathcal{M}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu} ; L, U)$ is more likely to be empty with larger $\zeta$.

Although Eckstein et al. (2021) used a different approach by incorporating additional maturities, a comparative analysis of reductions with their findings provides information on the significance of our results. In Eckstein et al. (2021, Table 4.3), focusing on uniform marginals and spread options, the reported price intervals are $[0.335,8.337]$ for a single period, $[0.416,8.254]$ for two periods and $[0.776,7.920]$ for four periods. Consequently, in their four-period scenario, the calculated ratio is $(7.920-0.776) /(8.337-0.335)=89.28 \%$, falling within the range observed in our Table 3.

![table_2](table_2)

Table 3: Basket option on GILD and GSK with tighter bounds (6.9) and (6.10).

# 6.3.3 Arbitrary weights 

To further assess the performance of McCormick MOT on basket options, we generalize the weight parameter for stock prices and define the option payoff as

$$
\max \left\{w_{1} X_{1}+w_{2} X_{2}+w_{3} Y_{1}+w_{4} Y_{2}-K, 0\right\}
$$

where $w_{1}+w_{2}+w_{3}+w_{4}=1$ and $w_{i} \geq 0$. Unlike the previous subsection, we only use the natural upper and lower bounds implied by marginal constraints.

We consider 100 arbitrarily chosen weight tuples $w:=\left(w_{1}, w_{2}, w_{3}, w_{4}\right)$. For each tuple, we test it on the underlying assets GILD and GSK, which have 247 distinct initial dates for the option. The strike price is set as the average of the forward prices for $X_{1}$ and $Y_{1}$, delivered at $T_{1}$. After calculating the ratios for each $w$ on each date, we obtain a $247 \times 100$ array of ratios, and present the statistics as follows.
(1) For each given weight $w$, Figure 3 shows the minimum ratio achievable across all dates. For most weight parameters, there is at least one date where the ratio falls below $90.00 \%$. Approximately half of the weight parameters result in a minimum ratio between $70.00 \%$ and $90.00 \%$.
(2) Similarly, we can analyze the data from another perspective. For each given date, Figure 4 shows the minimum ratio achievable across 100 possible weights. For over $85.00 \%$ of the 247 days considered, there exists at least one weight that yields a ratio lower than 0.9 .
(3) For each weight parameter, we calculate the average ratio across all dates. Figure 5 presents the histogram of these average ratios. Most weight parameters yield an average ratio between $94.00 \%$ and $98.00 \%$, consistent with the equal-weight case. However, there is a weight tuple that can achieve an average ratio of approximately $88.40 \%$.

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3: Minimum ratio achievable for a given weight $w$ across 247 dates.
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4: Minimum ratio achievable on a given date across 100 weight parameters.
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Figure 5: Average ratios across all dates with fixed weight parameters.

# 6.4 Digital options 

Motivated by digital options, we present another example where the option payoffs are represented by indicator functions at atoms. In this case, the expectation corresponds to the

probability at specific atom points. For numerical stability, we also set the notional amount as $\$ 10,000$. Then the expected payoff is given by

$$
10000 \int c\left(x_{1: 2}, y_{1: 2}\right) \pi\left(d x_{1: 2}, d y_{1: 2}\right)=10000 \times \pi\left(X_{1}=x_{1}, X_{2}=x_{2}, Y_{1}=y_{1}, Y_{2}=y_{2}\right)
$$

In all cases for digital options, only natural bounds implied by marginal constraints are used.

# 6.4.1 An illustrating example 

Suppose the initial stock prices are $X_{0}=2$ and $Y_{0}=3$, respectively.
(1) At time $t=1$, the stock price $X_{1}=1,2,3$ with probabilities $0.01,0.98,0.01$, respectively. $Y_{1}=2,3,4$ with probabilities $0.4,0.2,0.4$, respectively;
(2) At time $t=2$, the stock price $X_{2}=1,2,3$ with probabilities $0.04,0.92,0.04$, respectively. $Y_{2}=2,3,4$ with probabilities $0.4,0.2,0.4$, respectively.

Here, the asset $X$ exhibits very low volatility, while the asset $Y$ shows very high volatility.
Consider the payoff $c=10000 \times \mathbf{1}_{\left\{X_{1}=x_{1}, X_{2}=x_{2}, Y_{1}=y_{1}, Y_{2}=y_{2}\right\}}$. There are $3 \times 3 \times 3 \times 3=81$ combinations of $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, y_{1}, y_{2}\right)$. Given the small problem size, the bicausal MOT can be solved using a brute-force approach. We observe the following pattern: Bicausal or McCormick MOT may not improve prices, resulting in a ratio of 1.0. Only nine out of the 81 cases show price reductions. However, when the proposed methods do improve prices, the reductions are significant. The best case is shown in Table 4 for the event $\left\{X_{1}=2, X_{2}=3, Y_{1}=3, Y_{2}=3\right\}$, where both bicausal and McCormick MOT lead to the same price. In this case, the ratio is 0.0204 , indicating a $97.96 \%$ reduction in the price gap.

The average ratio across all 81 cases is $89.91 \%$. However, the mean may not be the best metric here. The ratio is either very close to 0 or exactly 1 . Therefore, we also report median values in subsequent examples.

Another observation is that bicausal and McCormick MOT yield the same prices in all 81 cases, highlighting the effectiveness of McCormick relaxations.

![table_3](table_3)

Table 4: The best case in the illustrative example. Bicausal MOT achieves identical prices to McCormick MOT and is therefore omitted.

In general, we can also consider payoffs depending on more general events, such as $\left\{X_{1} \leq\right.$ $\left.2, X_{2}=3, Y_{2} \geq 3\right\}$. The corresponding results are presented in Table 5. In this case, both the bicausal and McCormick MOT yield the same prices.

![table_4](table_4)

Table 5: Prices for the payoff as the indicator function of the event $\left\{X_{1} \leq 2, X_{2}=3, Y_{2} \geq 3\right\}$.

# 6.4.2 Empirical examples 

In Section 6.3, the marginals calibrated from empirical data result in thousands of possible cases, making it impractical to solve the bicausal MOT in a reasonable time. Therefore, this section only focuses on McCormick MOT for digital options. Notably, it can significantly reduce prices even with liquid options on assets such as JPM and MS.

As in Section 6.3, for each initial date $T_{0}$, the first maturity date $T_{1}$ is the one closest to $T_{0}$, and the second maturity date $T_{2}$ is roughly one month after $T_{1}$. Payoffs are indicator functions of all possible atom points $\left\{X_{1}=x_{1}, X_{2}=x_{2}, Y_{1}=y_{1}, Y_{2}=y_{2}\right\}$ after fixing the dates. Due to the large number of combinations, Table 6 presents results only for three arbitrarily chosen initial dates $T_{0}$. A similar pattern to the illustrative example is observed: The mean value of the ratio is significantly low, while the median is higher since prices are not reduced in about half of the cases.

![table_5](table_5)

The best cases for each initial date are presented in Table 7. It demonstrates that McCormick MOT is significantly more effective when the option payoffs directly depend on the probabilities. The bicausal constraints, or their relaxations, may exclude certain events.

To further illustrate the behavior of McCormick MOT on digital payoffs, Figures 6, 7, and 8 show the distribution of price ratios for the three initial dates listed in Table 6. While McCormick MOT may not always lead to price reductions, when improvements do occur, they are substantial. Moreover, in all three scenarios, the proportion of cases with price reductions exceeds $45.00 \%$.

# A Proofs of results 

Proof of Proposition 3.2. Define $f^{h}\left(x_{1: N}\right):=\int h_{t}\left(y_{1: t}\right) \pi\left(d y_{1: t} \mid x_{1: N}\right)$ with $h_{t} \in C_{b}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{1: t}\right)$. It is worth noting that $f^{h}\left(x_{1: N}\right)$ is defined $\pi$-almost surely. A coupling $\pi \in \Pi(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu})$ is causal if and only if

$$
f^{h}\left(x_{1: N}\right)=\int f^{h}\left(x_{1: t}, \bar{x}_{t+1: N}\right) \pi\left(d \bar{x}_{t+1: N} \mid x_{1: t}\right), \quad \pi \text {-a.s. }
$$

for all $1 \leq t \leq N$ and all $f^{h}$ defined with $h_{t} \in C_{b}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{1: t}\right)$. We emphasize that (A.1) holds $\pi$-almost surely, and the conditional kernel $\pi\left(d \bar{x}_{t+1: N} \mid x_{1: t}\right)$ depends on the choice of $\pi$ since the joint distribution of $X_{1: N}$ is not fixed.

Furthermore, (A.1) holds if and only if for any $g_{t} \in C_{b}\left(\mathcal{X}_{1: N}\right)$, we have

$$
\int g_{t}\left(x_{1: N}\right)\left[f^{h}\left(x_{1: N}\right)-\int f^{h}\left(x_{1: t}, \bar{x}_{t+1: N}\right) \pi\left(d \bar{x}_{t+1: N} \mid x_{1: t}\right)\right] \pi\left(d x_{1: N}\right)=0
$$

Interchanging the expectations on $x_{1: N}$ and $\bar{x}_{t+1: N}$ yields

$$
\int f^{h}\left(x_{1: N}\right)\left[g_{t}\left(x_{1: N}\right)-\int g_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, \bar{x}_{t+1: N}\right) \pi\left(d \bar{x}_{t+1: N} \mid x_{1: t}\right)\right] \pi\left(d x_{1: N}\right)=0
$$

Subsequently, utilizing the tower property, (A.3) is equivalent to

$$
\int h_{t}\left(y_{1: t}\right)\left[g_{t}\left(x_{1: N}\right)-\int g_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, \bar{x}_{t+1: N}\right) \pi\left(d \bar{x}_{t+1: N} \mid x_{1: t}\right)\right] \pi\left(d x_{1: N}, d y_{1: N}\right)=0
$$

Proof of Proposition 4.1. In the finite discrete case with the Euclidean topology, the convergence of probability masses $\pi^{n}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)$ to $\pi\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)$ is pointwise. Since $\mathcal{M}_{b c}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu})$ is characterized by linear and quadratic equalities, it is closed. Moreover, $\mathcal{M}_{b c}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu})$ is bounded and non-empty. By the Weierstrass theorem, the infimum is attained.

For the second part, suppose that the problem has an optimizer $\bar{\pi}$ in the interior of $\mathcal{M}_{b c}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu})$; otherwise, there is nothing to prove. Moreover, we can find a point $\pi^{*}$ on the boundary $\partial \mathcal{M}_{b c}$ that minimizes the Euclidean distance between $\partial \mathcal{M}_{b c}$ and $\bar{\pi}$. Let $\pi^{m}:=$ $2 \bar{\pi}-\pi^{*}$, such that $\bar{\pi}$ is the midpoint of the line segment joining $\pi^{m}$ and $\pi^{*}$.

Crucially, $\pi^{m}$ is in $\mathcal{M}_{b c}(\bar{\mu}, \bar{\nu})$. If not, there would exist another point between $\bar{\pi}$ and $\pi^{m}$ on $\partial \mathcal{M}_{b c}$ that is closer to $\bar{\pi}$ than $\pi^{*}$, leading to a contradiction.

The objective values corresponding to these transport plans satisfy

$$
\int c d \bar{\pi}=\frac{1}{2} \int c d \pi^{m}+\frac{1}{2} \int c d \pi^{*}
$$

Since $\bar{\pi}$ is an optimizer, it follows that

$$
\int c d \bar{\pi} \leq \int c d \pi^{m} \quad \text { and } \quad \int c d \bar{\pi} \leq \int c d \pi^{*}
$$

Hence, from (A.5)-(A.6), we obtain

$$
\int c d \bar{\pi}=\int c d \pi^{m} \quad \text { and } \quad \int c d \bar{\pi}=\int c d \pi^{*}
$$

Then $\pi^{*}$ on $\partial \mathcal{M}_{b c}$ must be an optimizer of the problem.
Proof of Theorem 5.5. If we substitute the cost $c$ with $c+C\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|x_{i}\right|+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left|y_{j}\right|\right)$, it only introduces a finite constant to the original problem, thanks to the finite first moments and marginal conditions. Consequently, we can assume $c \geq 0$ henceforth.

We endow $L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right)$ with the weak topology, where $f_{n}$ converges to $f$ in the weak topology if and only if

$$
\int f_{n} v d \lambda \rightarrow \int f v d \lambda, \quad \forall v \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right)
$$

Since every function in $\mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)$ is bounded by the same integrable function $u$, Bogachev (2007, Theorem 4.7.20 (v)) shows that $\mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)$ has a compact closure under the weak

topology of $L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right)$. If we can demonstrate that $\mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)$ is closed, then it is also compact.

Consider a sequence of functions $\left\{f_{n}\right\}$ in $\mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)$ that converges to $f$ in the weak topology of $L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right)$. This convergence is expressed as:

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int f_{n} v d \lambda=\int f v d \lambda
$$

First, select $v=\mathbf{1}_{A}$ with a measurable set $A$ in $\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}$. Since it holds that

$$
\int f_{n}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) v\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda \leq \int u\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) v\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda
$$

we can obtain that $f \leq u \lambda$-a.e. Similarly, we can show $f \geq l, \lambda$-a.e. Next, consider $v\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)=\psi\left(x_{1}\right) \in L^{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$. Then, $f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)$ has the marginal $g_{1}$ on $x_{1}$. Other marginal constraints can also be verified. To establish that $f$ satisfies the martingale constraint, we observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}} f_{n}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda\right. \\
& \left.\quad-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}} f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda\right] \\
& \leq\left|\int_{K} f_{n}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda-\int_{K} f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda\right| \\
& +\left|\int_{\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right) \backslash K} f_{n}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda\right. \\
& \left.\quad-\int_{\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right) \backslash K} f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

where $K:=[-a, a]^{N} \times[-a, a]^{N}$ is a compact set in $\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}$, and $\alpha_{t} \in L^{\infty}$. With a given compact set $K$, the first term converges to zero since $x_{t}$ and $x_{t+1}$ are bounded on $K$. The second term is bounded by $\left\|\alpha_{t}\right\|_{\infty} \varepsilon$ since $f_{n}$ and $f$ have marginals $(\bar{g}, \bar{h})$ with finite first moments. Here, $\varepsilon$ is a generic constant such that

$$
\int_{\left(\mathbb{R}^{N} \times \mathbb{R}^{N}\right) \backslash K} f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)\left|x_{t}\right| d \lambda<\varepsilon
$$

This same constant $\varepsilon$ also bounds other similar integrals, where $f_{n}$ and/or $x_{t+1}$ are used instead. When the side width $a \rightarrow \infty$, we have $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$. Consequently, $f$ also satisfies the martingale constraint. In summary, the limit $f \in \mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)$, and the compactness follows.

The proof of the lower semicontinuity for the objective is standard. When $c$ is bounded, the functional

$$
f \mapsto \int c f d \lambda
$$

is continuous, following from the definition of weak topology. In the case where $c$ is nonnegative but unbounded, there exists a sequence of bounded measurable functions $\left\{c_{n}\right\}$ converging increasingly to $c$. Using the monotone convergence theorem, we have

$$
\int f c d \lambda=\int f \sup _{n} c_{n} d \lambda=\sup _{n} \int f c_{n} d \lambda
$$

demonstrating that $\int f c d \lambda$ is a supremum of continuous functionals and, consequently, l.s.c. The claim then follows as the infimum is attained for an l.s.c. functional on a compact set.

Proof of Lemma 5.6. Similarly to the proof of Villani (2003, Proposition 1.22), we can substitute the cost $c$ for $c+C(1+|x|+|y|)+\varepsilon$ for an arbitrarily large $\varepsilon>0$. With the finite first moments and marginal conditions, this modification adds the same finite constant to both sides of the strong duality. The result for the modified cost implies the result for the original cost function $c$. Hence, we proceed with the assumption $c \geq \varepsilon>0$ in the subsequent analysis.

Define the functionals $\Xi$ and $\Theta$ as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Xi & :(b(x, y), \kappa(x, y)) \in C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}) \times C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}) \\
& \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\int \phi(x) g(x) d x+\int \varphi(y) h(y) d y-\int \kappa(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y \\
\quad \text { if } b(x, y)=\phi(x)+\varphi(y) \text { and } \kappa(x, y) \leq 0 \\
+\infty, \text { else. }
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Theta & :(b(x, y), \kappa(x, y)) \in C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}) \times C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}) \\
& \mapsto\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0, \text { if } b(x, y) \geq-c(x, y)+\kappa(x, y) \text { and } \kappa(x, y) \leq 0 \\
+\infty, \text { else. }
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Xi$ is well-defined. Specifically, if $\phi(x)+\varphi(y)=\tilde{\phi}(x)+\tilde{\varphi}(y)$ for all $x$ and $y$, then $\phi=\tilde{\phi}+s$ and $\varphi=\tilde{\varphi}-s$ with a constant $s$; see Villani (2003, Section 1.1, p.27) for the same argument. Analogously, $\Theta$ is also well-defined.

To verify the assumptions in Fenchel-Rockafellar duality theorem (Villani, 2003, Theorem 1.9), we observe that $\Xi$ and $\Theta$ are finite at $(b, \kappa)=(0,-1)$. Moreover, under conditions $\|b\|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon$ and $\|\kappa+1\|_{\infty} \leq \frac{1}{2}$, it follows that $\kappa \leq 0$ and $-c+\kappa \leq-\varepsilon \leq b$. Consequently, $\Theta(0,-1)=0$, and therefore $\Theta$ is continuous at $(0,-1)$.

A direct calculation yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \inf _{(b, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b}}[\Theta(b, \kappa)+\Xi(b, \kappa)] \\
& =\inf _{(\phi, \varphi, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b} \times C_{b}}\left[\int \phi(x) g(x) d x+\int \varphi(y) h(y) d y-\int \kappa(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y\right] \\
& \phi(x)+\varphi(y) \geq-c(x, y)+\kappa(x, y), \kappa \leq 0] \\
& =-\sup _{(\phi, \varphi, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b} \times C_{b}}\left[\int \phi(x) g(x) d x+\int \varphi(y) h(y) d y-\int \kappa(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y\right] \\
& \phi(x)+\varphi(y) \leq c(x, y)+\kappa(x, y), \kappa \geq 0]
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last equality, we substitute $(\phi, \varphi, \kappa)$ with $(-\phi,-\varphi,-\kappa)$.
A challenge arises due to the fact that the topological dual of $C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$, denoted as $\left(C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})\right)^{*}$, is greater than $M(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$, which represents the set of all finite signed measures. To calculate the Legendre-Fenchel transforms of $\Theta$ and $\Xi$, we take advantage of Villani (2003, Lemmas 1.24 and 1.25) to deal with continuous linear functionals on $C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$. In addition,

we note that the topological dual of the product space $C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}) \times C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$ is the product of dual spaces, namely $\left(C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})\right)^{*} \times\left(C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})\right)^{*}$.

With linear forms $\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right) \in\left(C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})\right)^{*} \times\left(C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})\right)^{*}$, the Legendre-Fenchel transform of $\Theta$ is defined as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right) \\
& =\sup _{(b, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b}}\left[\left\langle-l_{1}, b\right\rangle+\left\langle-l_{2}, \kappa\right\rangle \mid b(x, y) \geq-c(x, y)+\kappa(x, y), \kappa(x, y) \leq 0\right] \\
& =\sup _{(b, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b}}\left[\left\langle l_{1}, b-\kappa\right\rangle+\left\langle l_{1}+l_{2}, \kappa\right\rangle \mid b(x, y) \leq c(x, y)+\kappa(x, y), \kappa(x, y) \geq 0\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\langle\cdot, \cdot\rangle$ denotes the duality bracket (Villani, 2003, p. xiv).
Next, we identify the conditions for $\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)<+\infty$ and compute $\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)$. If there exists $v \geq 0$ satisfying $\left\langle l_{1}+l_{2}, v\right\rangle>0$, then we can choose $b=\kappa=k v$ and send $k \rightarrow \infty$. Similarly, if there exists $v \geq 0$ and $\left\langle l_{1}, v\right\rangle<0$, then we can consider $\kappa=0$ and $b=-k v$ with $k \rightarrow \infty$. Therefore, $\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)<+\infty$ only when $l_{1}$ is nonnegative and $l_{1}+l_{2}$ is nonpositive.

Furthermore, the Legendre-Fenchel transform of $\Xi$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)=\sup _{(b, \kappa) \in C_{b} \times C_{b}}[ & \left\langle l_{1}, b\right\rangle+\left\langle l_{2}, \kappa\right\rangle-\int \phi(x) g(x) d x-\int \varphi(y) h(y) d y \\
& \left.+\int \kappa(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y \mid b(x, y)=\phi(x)+\varphi(y) \text { and } \kappa(x, y) \leq 0\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

To avoid $\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)=+\infty$, we first need

$$
\left\langle l_{1}, \phi+\varphi\right\rangle=\int \phi(x) g(x) d x+\int \varphi(y) h(y) d y
$$

It is noteworthy that $l_{1}$ should be nonnegative, as argued above. Moreover, $l_{1}$ also acts continuously on the subset $C_{0}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$ of $C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$, where $C_{0}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$ denotes the set of all continuous functions approaching 0 at infinity. Since the topological dual of $C_{0}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$ is $M(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$, there exists a unique measure $\pi \in M(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})$ such that

$$
\left\langle l_{1}, v\right\rangle=\int v(x, y) d \pi, \quad \forall v \in C_{0}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})
$$

We can then decompose $l_{1}=\pi+R$, where $R$ is a continuous linear functional with

$$
\langle R, v\rangle=0, \quad \forall v \in C_{0}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})
$$

Under the condition (A.10), Villani (2003, Lemma 1.25) shows that $R=0$, and $l_{1}=\pi$ is a nonnegative measure with Borel marginals $g d x$ and $h d y$.

Another requirement to avoid $\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)=+\infty$ is

$$
\left\langle l_{2}, \kappa\right\rangle+\int \kappa(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y \leq 0, \quad \forall \kappa(x, y) \leq 0, \kappa \in C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})
$$

Since $l_{1}+l_{2}$ is nonpositive and $l_{1}$ is a measure, then

$$
\left\langle l_{1}+l_{2}, v\right\rangle=\int v(x, y) d \pi+\left\langle l_{2}, v\right\rangle \leq 0, \quad \forall v(x, y) \geq 0, v \in C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})
$$

Together with (A.11), setting $\kappa=-v$ yields

$$
\int v(x, y) d \pi \leq-\left\langle l_{2}, v\right\rangle \leq \int v(x, y) u(x, y) d x d y, \quad \forall v(x, y) \geq 0, v \in C_{b}(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R})
$$

This implies that $\pi$ is absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure $\lambda$ on the Borel $\sigma$-algebra of $\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}$. Otherwise, suppose that the opposite is true. Then, there exists a Borel set $B$ such that $\lambda(B)=0$ and $\pi(B)>0$. Since $\pi$ is regular (Bertsekas and Shreve, 1978, Proposition 7.17), there exists a closed subset $F \subset B$ and $\pi(F)>\delta>0$ for a small $\delta$. Similar to the proof of Bertsekas and Shreve (1978, Proposition 7.18), let $G_{n}=\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} \mid d((x, y), F)<1 / n\}$ with a sufficiently large $n$. By Urysohn's lemma, there exist continuous functions $0 \leq v_{n} \leq 1$ such that $v_{n}=0$ on $G_{n}^{c}$ and $v_{n}=1$ on $F$. Then

$$
\pi(F) \leq \int v_{n}(x, y) d \pi \leq \int v_{n}(x, y) u(x, y) d \lambda \leq\|u\|_{\infty} \int v_{n} d \lambda \leq\|u\|_{\infty} \lambda\left(G_{n}\right)
$$

which implies

$$
\pi(F) \leq\|u\|_{\infty} \lambda\left(\cap_{n=1}^{\infty} G_{n}\right)=\|u\|_{\infty} \lambda(F) \leq\|u\|_{\infty} \lambda(B)=0
$$

leading to a contradiction with $\pi(F)>\delta>0$. By the Radon-Nikodým theorem (Rogers and Williams, 1993, Theorem 9.3, p.98), the Radon-Nikodým density exists: $f(x, y)=\frac{d \pi}{d \lambda}$, $\lambda$-a.e.

Furthermore, (A.13) implies $f(x, y) \leq u(x, y), \lambda$-a.e. Otherwise, suppose $\lambda(B)>0$, where $B:=\{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} \mid f(x, y)>u(x, y)\} . B$ is a Borel set. Since $\lambda$ is regular, there exists a closed subset $F \subset B$ and $\lambda(F)>0$. Introducing continuous and bounded functions $v_{n}$ similarly as before, (A.13) and the dominated convergence theorem lead to

$$
\int \mathbf{1}_{F} f d \lambda \leq \int v_{n} f d \lambda \leq \int v_{n} u d \lambda \leq \int \mathbf{1}_{G_{n}} u d \lambda \rightarrow \int \mathbf{1}_{F} u d \lambda
$$

which contradicts the fact that $f>u$ on $F$ and $\lambda(F)>0$.
In summary, $\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)+\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)<+\infty$ requires that $l_{1}$ is a probability measure in $\Pi(g, h)$ with density $0 \leq f \leq u$ and $l_{1}+l_{2}$ is nonpositive. Clearly, the reverse direction is also true: If $l_{1}$ is a probability measure in $\Pi(g, h)$ with density $0 \leq f \leq u$ and $l_{1}+l_{2}$ is nonpositive, then $\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)+\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)<+\infty$.

Moreover, when $l_{1}$ is a probability measure in $\Pi(g, h)$ with density $0 \leq f \leq u$ and $l_{1}+l_{2}$ is nonpositive, it follows that $\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)=0$ and

$$
\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)=\sup _{b \in C_{b}}\left[\int b(x, y) f(x, y) d x d y \mid b(x, y) \leq c(x, y)\right]=\int c(x, y) f(x, y) d x d y
$$

because the l.s.c. cost $c \geq \varepsilon$ can be approximated pointwise by a monotonically increasing sequence of continuous and bounded functions. Then the equality above follows from the

monotone convergence theorem. Therefore, the right-hand side of the Fenchel-Rockafellar duality reduces to

$$
\max _{\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right) \in\left(C_{b}\right)^{*} \times\left(C_{b}\right)^{*}}\left[-\Theta^{*}\left(-l_{1},-l_{2}\right)-\Xi^{*}\left(l_{1}, l_{2}\right)\right] \quad=-\min _{f \in \Pi(g, h ; u)} \int c(x, y) f(x, y) d x d y
$$

We have proved the strong duality (5.19), albeit with continuous and bounded $(\phi, \varphi, \kappa)$. In the $L^{1}$ case, the claim follows from

$$
\inf _{f \in \Pi(g, h ; u)} P(f)=\sup _{\Psi_{c} \cap C_{b}} F(\phi, \varphi, \kappa) \leq \sup _{\Psi_{c}} F(\phi, \varphi, \kappa) \leq \inf _{f \in \Pi(g, h ; u)} P(f)
$$

where the last inequality is a result of weak duality, similar to Villani (2003, Proposition 1.5). In addition, in the first equality, the notation $\Psi_{c} \cap C_{b}$ indicates that $(\phi, \varphi, \kappa)$ are also continuous and bounded.

Proof of Theorem 5.7. Similarly to the proof of Lemma 5.6, we can assume the cost $c \geq 0$.
Consider a continuous and bounded cost $c$. Maximization in the dual problem can be achieved in two steps. First, we maximize over $(\phi, \varphi, \kappa)$ when other multipliers $(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, \theta)$ are given. This reduces to a dual problem with the upper capacity constraint in Lemma 5.6, but with a new cost given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tilde{c}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}, \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, \theta ; u, l\right) \\
& =c\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)-\theta\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \\
& \quad+\sum_{t=1}^{N-1} \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right)+\sum_{t=1}^{N-1} \beta_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(y_{t+1}-y_{t}\right) \\
& \quad+\Psi\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}, \gamma, \eta ; u, l\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

On the basis of our assumptions, we have $c, \theta, \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, u, l \in C_{b}$. Hence, $\tilde{c}$ is continuous, and $|\tilde{c}| \leq C\left(1+\sum_{t=1}^{N}\left|x_{t}\right|+\sum_{t=1}^{N}\left|y_{t}\right|\right)$. An application of Lemma 5.6 leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
D & =\sup _{\substack{\alpha_{t}, \beta_{t} \\
\gamma_{t, i}, \eta_{i, i} \geq 0 \\
\theta \geq 0}} \sup _{\Phi_{c} \text { with }\left(\alpha_{t}, \beta_{t}, \gamma_{t, i}, \eta_{i, i}, \theta\right)} D(\phi, \varphi, \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, \kappa, \theta) \\
& =\sup _{\substack{\alpha_{t}, \beta_{t} \\
\gamma_{t, i}, \eta_{i, i} \geq 0 \\
\theta \geq 0}} \inf _{\substack{f \in \Pi(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; u) \\
\Phi \geq 0}} \int \tilde{c}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}, \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, \theta ; u, l\right) f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda \\
& =\inf _{\substack{f \in \Pi(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; u) \\
\gamma_{t, i}, \eta_{i, i} \geq 0 \\
\theta \geq 0}} \sup _{\substack{\alpha_{t}, \beta_{t} \\
\gamma_{t, i}, \eta_{i, i} \geq 0 \\
\theta \geq 0}} \int \tilde{c}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}, \alpha, \beta, \gamma, \eta, \theta ; u, l\right) f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda \\
& =\inf _{f \in \mathcal{M}(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; l, u)} \int c\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda=P
\end{aligned}
$$

(A.17) follows from the minimax theorem, given in Strasser (1985, Theorem 45.8, p. 239) or Beiglböck et al. (2013, Theorem 3.1). In fact, $\Pi(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; u)$ is compact in the weak topology of $L^{1}$. Since $\tilde{c}$ has a linear growth rate and the marginals have finite first moments, we can

also prove that the objective $\int \tilde{c} f d \lambda$ is continuous in $f \in \Pi(\bar{g}, \bar{h} ; u)$ using the weak topology of $L^{1}$, similar to the approach in Beiglböck et al. (2013, Lemma 2.2).

The final equality (A.18) is derived from the observation that any violation of the martingale condition, the McCormick relaxations, or the lower bound results in an infinite value.

In the case of a nonnegative and l.s.c. cost function $c$, the strong duality can be established through a standard approximation argument. For example, see the last part of the proof presented in Beiglböck et al. (2013, Theorem 1.1).

Proof of Proposition 6.1. The proof is straightforward. Clearly, the objective and constraints in (6.2)-(6.6) are linear. If the optimal value is finite, then the optimizer $\mu$ exists. The constraints (6.3)-(6.6) ensure that $\mu$ is a risk-neutral measure, yielding forward prices $F_{t}$ and option prices $c_{i, t}$. By the property of absolute values, the smallest value of $\left|c_{i, t}-a_{i, t}\right|+\left|c_{i, t}-b_{i, t}\right|$ is given by $\left|a_{i, t}-b_{i, t}\right|$, which implies that $c_{i, t} \in\left[b_{i, t}, a_{i, t}\right]$. The claim follows.

# B Additional details on the derivation of the dual problem (5.17) 

With the Lagrange multipliers introduced in Section 5.2.1, the Lagrangian should include the following components:
(1) Terms related to the marginal constraints, given by

$$
\int \phi_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\left(g_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)-f\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \lambda\left(d x_{t}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \int \varphi_{t}\left(y_{t}\right)\left(h_{t}\left(y_{t}\right)-f\left(y_{t}\right)\right) \lambda\left(d y_{t}\right)
$$

(2) Terms related to the martingale constraints, given by

$$
\int f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \alpha_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(x_{t+1}-x_{t}\right) d \lambda
$$

and

$$
\int f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) \beta_{t}\left(x_{1: t}, y_{1: t}\right)\left(y_{t+1}-y_{t}\right) d \lambda
$$

(3) Terms related to the McCormick relaxations. For simplicity, we provide two examples, with others obtained similarly. The term related to the first inequality in the McCormick relaxation of the causality condition is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \gamma_{t, 1}\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right)( & -w\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right)+l\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right) f\left(x_{1: t}\right) \\
& +f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right) l\left(x_{1: t}\right)-l\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right) l\left(x_{1: t}\right)\rangle \lambda\left(d x_{1: N}, d y_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The term related to the first inequality in the McCormick relaxation of the anticausality condition is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \eta_{t, 1}\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right)( & -\tilde{w}\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right)+l\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right) f\left(y_{1: t}\right) \\
& +f\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right) l\left(y_{1: t}\right)-l\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right) l\left(y_{1: t}\right)\rangle \lambda\left(d x_{t}, d y_{1: N}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{w}\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right)$ is the anticausal counterpart of $w\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right)$;

(4) Terms related to the upper and lower bounds, given by

$$
\int \kappa\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)\left(f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)-u\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)\right) d \lambda
$$

and

$$
\int \theta\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)\left(l\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)-f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)\right) d \lambda
$$

(5) The primal objective itself, i.e., $\int c\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right) d \lambda$.

Heuristically, with the Lagrangian above, we interchange the infimum with the supremum, group terms by $w\left(x_{1: N}, y_{t}\right), \tilde{w}\left(x_{t}, y_{1: N}\right)$, and $f\left(x_{1: N}, y_{1: N}\right)$, and finally obtain the dual problem in (5.17).

abstract:
Martingale optimal transport (MOT) often yields broad price bounds for
options, constraining their practical applicability. In this study, we extend
MOT by incorporating causality constraints among assets, inspired by the
nonanticipativity condition of stochastic processes. This, however, introduces
a computationally challenging bilinear program. To tackle this issue, we
propose McCormick relaxations to ease the bicausal formulation and refer to it
as McCormick MOT. The primal attainment and strong duality of McCormick MOT are
established under standard assumptions. Empirically, we apply McCormick MOT to
basket and digital options. With natural bounds on probability masses, the
average price reduction for basket options is approximately 1.08% to 3.90%.
When tighter probability bounds are available, the reduction increases to
12.26%, compared to the classic MOT, which also incorporates tighter bounds.
For most dates considered, there are basket options with suitable payoffs,
where the price reduction exceeds 10.00%. For digital options, McCormick MOT
results in an average price reduction of over 20.00%, with the best case
exceeding 99.00%.
